justification: "Typical paradigms involve choices between a smaller but sooner (often immediate) reward and a larger reward with a longer delay" – describing the delay discounting task used to assess temporal discounting.

measured_by: cognitive effort discounting task using visual search difficulty
justification: The text notes participants may choose between a low-effort baseline and a high-reward, high-effort offer "using a visual search of differing difficulties to manipulate levels of cognitive effort" (Chong et al., 2017).

measured_by: physical effort discounting task using grip-force levels
justification: A separate task is described where participants "squeeze a grip force device" with varying percentages of maximum strength to obtain rewards, capturing physical effort discounting.
In Figure 1B the review presents "tasks measuring decisions under uncertainty involving risk… In risk tasks the uncertain option has known probabilities" illustrated with a spinner lottery.
The same figure contrasts risk with ambiguity, stating that "in ambiguous tasks they have unknown probabilities," identifying the task that measures ambiguity attitude.
"The monetary incentive delay task (MID)… was designed to examine similar patterns of activity using human fMRI," and is introduced as the paradigm for studying reward anticipation.
Figure 3B is described as the "Two-step task used to separate habitual from goal-directed or 'model-free' from 'model-based' learning (Daw et al., 2011)."

measured_by: go / no-go task with reward and punishment cues
justification: Figure 3C shows a task "to measure Pavlovian biases during learning (e.g. Guitart-Masip et al., 2012)" where participants make go or no-go responses to rewarded or punished cues.

The review explains that "common tasks to assess reinforcement learning require participants to learn associations by selecting one of two symbols and observing the outcome (e.g. Pessiglione et al., 2006)."
